paragraphs.context: Following the utilitarian principle of seeking the greatest good for the greatest number – economic inequality is problematic. A house that provides less utility to a millionaire as a summer home that would do it to a homeless family of five, is an example of reduced "distributive efficiency" within society, which diminishes the marginal utility of wealth and therefore the total sum of personal utility. An additional dollar spent by a poor person will go to things that provide a lot of utility to that person, such as basic needs such as food, water, and health care; whereas, an additional dollar spent by a much richer person will most likely go to luxury items that provide relatively less utility to that person. Thus, the marginal utility of wealth per person ("the additional dollar") decreases as a person becomes richer. From this point of view, for any given amount of wealth in society, a society with more equality will have more added utility.
